physDesc.p: Letter consists of 3 pages of typerwriter text. Includes the words "Monroe" and "Poerty" in handwiring at top of the front page above the opener. Date line appears twice at the top at of the first page as a likely result of a typewriter malfunction.

div.p: I am afraid you think me perfectly horrid not to take Mr. Fuller’s suggestions, but you tell me I am conceited enough to think I am as good an authority on English Grammar as any one in the world. One writer cannot know what flavour the other writers [sic] words ought to have. To use “one another” and “thus far” would immediately turn the sentences into an academic and preceiux form of language, the stilted kind which we are all trying very hard to get away from. Mr. Fuller would never make an error of taste in his own writings, which are most dignified and beautiful and in excellent proportion, but I do not admit that he, or any one else, is a good critic of other people’s prose.

You could have far more justly pounced upon the word “apter” which I think does not exist. I, myself, think the secret of good writing is to be willing to do things of that kind when the flavour requires it. At any rate, it is a liberty which I shall always take, even if I am, although, I trust, sparingly, condemned for it.

Mrs. Russell writes me that she had a very pleasant talk with you over the telephone, and that you asked her to come and see you. I hope that that will come off, for I know you would like each other very much.
Please forgive my obstinacy, but after one has passed the nursery stage, one has a certain self reliance, and I am not of the kind that cares a button for authority.
I may be annoying as a contributor, but you must admit I am splendid at getting you subscriptions.

postscript.p: P.S. For your greater comfort let me say that I did not mean “one another,” but “each the other,” namely that [illegible text] inhibits the one with which it has to do, which would of course be the chemical action from which the simile is taken, not that each characteristic eliminates all the rest.

P.P.S. I do wish you had not been afraid to print that review of mine on Charles Hanson Towne’s book. One of Braithwaite’s minions has just given him a great send-off in the Transcript, and it does seem a shame that no dissenting voice should be heard.
